physical_appearance:This is a small censer. It is engraved decoratively with carvings. The lid is depicted as a turtle. There is a small handle on the right of the lid in the shape of a turtle head.

sgcool_label_text:This small censer is engraved decoratively with carvings which depict the lid as a turtle. In Chinese symbolism
 turtles signify long life and would be an appropriate motif for the ancestral altar. Incense and ashes would be placed within the body of the turtle and a small hole at the top would allow the smoke of incense to escape.\r\n\r\nThis item is donated by the family of prominent Peranakan
 Ong Sam Leong (b. 1857
 Singapore – d. 7 February 1918
 Singapore). It comes from his ancestral home of Bukit Rose
 formerly at 259 Bukit Timah Road. Ong was a well-known successful businessman who made is money in the mining of phosphate on Christmas island
 which was historically a territory of colonial Singapore.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a small censer. It is engraved decoratively with carvings. The lid is depicted as a turtle. There is a small handle on the right of the lid in the shape of a turtle head.

metadata.sgcool_label_text:
This small censer is engraved decoratively with carvings which depict the lid as a turtle. In Chinese symbolism, turtles signify long life and would be an appropriate motif for the ancestral altar. Incense and ashes would be placed within the body of the turtle and a small hole at the top would allow the smoke of incense to escape.

This item is donated by the family of prominent Peranakan, Ong Sam Leong (b. 1857, Singapore – d. 7 February 1918, Singapore). It comes from his ancestral home of Bukit Rose, formerly at 259 Bukit Timah Road. Ong was a well-known successful businessman who made is money in the mining of phosphate on Christmas island, which was historically a territory of colonial Singapore.
